title: Can I read a 1,000 books a year? - Quora

response.answer_text: Let’s think about this mathematically. If you throw comprehension out the window and just scan every page (looking for jokes or interesting names, maybe? Honestly, I have no idea why anyone would do this), I would say, from timing myself skimming a random page of the nearest book, you could read at a rate of 3 seconds per page. Let’s assume you’re “reading” a bunch of short books, so you can fit in as many as possible in a single day. If you take a year off from work, hobbies, etc. and take up page scanning for ten hours a day, you end up with 36,000 seconds of reading time, which (using the above metric) translates to an extraordinary 12,000 pages a day. If you can keep this up for a whole year, I admire your stamina. A quick Google search shows that an average book contains approximately 200–500 page, so let’s say 200 in order to cut down on unnecessary reading. Therefore, every day you could conceivably skim 60 books. In a year, you could get through 21,900 books- more than twenty times your desired number! Luckily, that’s far less than the total number of books in the English language, which is almost 130 million. But let’s do something more realistic. Instead of proudly boasting that you’ve looked at more than 21,000 books in one year, you decide that you want to understand what you’re reading. Doing another quick reading timing test, I came up with a reading speed of 50 seconds per page. Instead of 200 pages, let’s give your books an average of 500 pages. Once again, you devote ten hours a day (36,000 seconds) to reading, allowing you to read 720 pages per day. Plenty more reasonable than before, but it’s not looking good for your book count. In a year, keeping the same pace, you can expect to read around 262,800 pages. The grand total comes to… 525 books (and getting about halfway through another) Which is still an impressive accomplishment! Unfortunately, it’s unlikely that you will remember many of the details of the books you’re read. On the bright side, you will have probably set a Guiness World Record. Keep track of the books you read. It might come in handy.

Yes, if you read fast, limit yourself to short and easy books, and spent most of your free time doing so. I’ve read 498 “books” this year so far; mostly short genre novels, young adult, and a fair number of novellas and novelettes. That’s likely a personal best, though I haven’t always counted — I basically hibernated most of the year and read unusually much, and furthermore unusually much simplistic escapist “junk”. I can easily plow through 2 or more of such books a day, but I also read some books that took several days to finish. If you were to read 3 shortish works a day, which is entirely possible if you let go of your social life, you’d be reading 1095 books. You could read even more, or have more of a life, if you read only children’s or teen books. What most people probably can’t do, is read 1000 books of quality literature (which can also include genre fiction), or 100o nonfiction books, unless they don’t have a job. Skimming doesn’t count; ”reading” means understanding what you’ve read and being able to talk about the book’s story, theme, and characters afterwards. It’s easy to figure out for yourself how many pages you could read; just time yourself for a number of pages of average page count (generally that’s about 300 words), and then divide by the number to find out your time per page. Then you can calculate an average page count for the types of books you read, and see how many you could manage in the amount of time you have per day.

Well in theory it’s possible, if you have lots of time to do it and read fast. I normally read a 300~400 page book in about 1 hour if I like the book, and we got 365 days. So to get to 1000 books we need to read multiple books. If we take my time of 1 hour to read we can read about 14 books a day, unless you don’t sleep or sleep less, but let’s just take 14 books a day. Now let’s do this amazing math stuff to show of my skills, 14 * 365 is what we need, and that is 5110 books in a year. Wow, that’s like 4110 books more than you want, that means we even get free time and don’t have to read a book every hour we’re awake! I don’t know about your reading speed, but with this calculation you can take it pretty slow, 3 books a day would grant you 1095 books in a year, so you can even take a day off without a problem! Now let’s get to what would really happen if we try that. I would definitly run out of books to read pretty soon, and I would get tired of reading after reading that much a day. So to get to the point, yes it’s possible, but I don’t think we can keep it up that long unless you have tons of money to spent on books and are really motivated to get to 1000 books a year.

I really doubt it, unless you have all day to read and you’re a fast reader. It depends how fast you read, how much free time you have, your discipline to spend lots of time reading etc. Do you have a full-time job and you intend to read in the evenings? Or do you have a full-time course of study? If yes to either of those, let’s assume you have 3–4 hours per 24 hour period that you might put into reading. How long does it take you to read one book? If you’re a fast reader, you might finish one book per 3 to 4 hours (depends on book length) and therefore read 365 books per year. To finish 1,000 books per year, I think you would need to be spending the majority of your daytime (12 hours) just on reading - no time to go to a full-time job or go to school.

You probably could. If it’s fiction, you’d not have to think much about the content. You could consume and imagine things which you read about, with little “processing”. For non-fiction, it’d be very impractical. I’ve tried getting closer to 25–30 books a year, but I started to have a problem with knowledge processing. If the book contains charts, graphs, exercises etc. and I need to make couple of sketches and play with thoughts and concepts in my head, it’s starts to be very hard.

Depends on your reading speed, and, to some extent, how much time per day you are willing to sacrifice to this project. Also the size of the book. Could I read 1000 books in a year? Yes. IF I was independently wealthy, had servants who could cope with the day-to-day tasks like cooking, cleaning, grocery and clothes shopping, AND I was willing to alienate every single person I knew who could be a distraction (all my friends and family would fall into this category.) On the whole, though, I think I'd rather not.

I think others have addressed the physical plausibility of this idea. But why? One of the few things I’ve learned to be true is something Thoreau once wrote: “Books must be read as deliberately and reservedly as they were written” (i.e. slowly).
Others have covered the math, so I will go in another direction: why would you want to read 1000 books a year? I can't think of a good reason to do so.
Books here are not pages or words specific. So select books having minimum pages, and make a record. Best wishes.
